app.note: According to NR's note, this word is written at the beginning of the third line.
All known grants of Jayasiṁha I mentioning Asanapura use the term asanapura-vāsakāt.
The correct reading may be mahāsenenābhivarddhitānān tribhuvana-mātr̥bhir mmātr̥bhir abhirakṣitānāṁ. Compare line 2 of the Timmapuram plates of Viṣṇuvardhana I.

Normally, Kīrtīvarman's name is in the standard genitive kīrttīvarmaṇaḥ. The non-standard form kīrttīvarmasya may have been used here, or the correct reading might be ya, for kīrttīvarmaṇaḥ priya-naptā, as in the Guḍivāḍa plates (set 2) of Jayasiṁha I.

I wonder if this character is in fact an initial Ai, as in the Guḍivāḍa plates (set 2) of Jayasiṁha I where kīrttīvarmaṇaḥ priya-naptā is followed by Aidaṁyugīna-mahā-viṣṇoḥ viṣṇuvarddhana-mahārājasya priya-tanayaḥ.

In the Guḍivāḍa plates (set 2) of Jayasiṁha I, which seem to be a close parallel for this grant, the term pravarddhamāna-pratāpopanata-samasta-sāmanta-maṇḍalaḥ describing Jayasiṁha is followed by sva-śakti-traya-triśūlāvabhinna-para-narapati-sakala-bala-cetanaḥ. NR's samā may thus be a misreading of sva-śa.
NR is probably correct in assuming that this is the title sarvasiddhi, but this title of Jayasiṁha I is never, as far as I presently know, explained with apratihata-śaktitva.
The spelling of this name is nātavāḍi in the ARIE report and natavāḍi in NR's discussion. Other Eastern Cālukya grants use nātavāḍi or nātāvāḍi.
I adopt the name as reported in ARIE, which is usually reliable. NR only uses the dental t both in his Devanagari edition and in his Romanisation in the discussion.
NR repeats this phrase in his discussion, interpreting it to mean twice 12 khaṇḍikās. This is possible, but not paralleled in any related grant that I know. I wonder if dvi is in fact deleted.

I wonder if the word intended here was in fact pautrāya. This would result in a more typical formulation of the donee's descent, and would also eliminate the strangeness of father and son bearing the same name.

Scribal omission is also possible here; the composer's intent may have been nimitteneyam. However, since related grants normally use nimitte in the locative, it is more likely that this is a case of non-standard sandhi, or possibly of inaccurate gender use (nimitte + ayam).
NR's actual spelling in his edition is kenacit bādhā (with a tb conjunct), but I assume that the original has a final T here.

This reading is doubtful. According to NR's discussion, the grant was made in the presence of the Queen Triloka Mahādevī. I know of no such queen, and even NR seems not to trust his own reading/interpretation, since according to his introduction, the grant does not contain any new unknown or additional information about the Eastern Cālukyan chronology or genealogy. If the reading can be checked against the original and a queen by this name is indeed indicated, then this is important new information. More likely, the correct reading is something else. One of Jayasiṁha I's epithets is trailokya-vikrama, which may have been featured or indicated here. As for sammukhaṁ, I wonder if the correct reading is in fact samukha (for sva-mukha).
According to NR's discussion, the executor was called Buggi. He does not discuss the damaged characters before these.

div.head: Plates
div.p: From the majestic residence at Asanapura. The grandson of Kīrtivarman, who the family of the Calukyas—who are empowered by Mahāsena, who are protected by the Mothers who are mothers of the three worlds who are of the Mānavya gotra —the son of His Majesty Viṣṇuvardhana, who circleThis was probably a reference to subduing the circle of rival rulers, to conquering the circle of the earth, or to perfuming the circle of the horizon with his glory. King Jayasiṁha Vallabha, who has subdued the circle of rival rulers sāmanta who is all-accomplishing sarva-siddhi thanks to his incontestable power

The plot of land named Sarvvarddhi Relluvaṭṭi on the eastern boundary of the village named Uccāṭi in Nātavāḍi district, to the extent sufficient for sowing twice twelveOr perhaps just twelve; see the apparatus to line 9. khaṇḍikas of seed—this plot of land has been given by us, Jayasiṁha with exemption from all taxes, in order to augment the merit of our mother and father and ourselves on the occasion of vyatīpātaVyatīpāta is an astronomical moment at which the declinations of the moon and sun are of equal magnitude, related to the prediction of eclipses (
). in the month of Vaiśākha, to Mātr̥śarman, a knower of the Veda learned in six śāstras, son of Mātr̥śarman who was a knower of pada recitation and who was in turn son of Durganandiśarman,It is possible that the text is erroneous here (see the apparatus to line 11); the donee's father was perhaps Durganandiśarman, and the donee perhaps bore the same name as his grandfather Mātr̥śarman. a knower of two Vedas residing in Vaṁgipaṟu, of the Āpastamba school and the Kaṇva gotra. Let no-one pose an obstacle to his enjoyment of his rights over it. There are moreover these ślokas sung by Vyāsa.
Many kings have granted land, and many have preserved it as formerly granted. Whosoever at any time owns the land, the fruit reward accrued of granting it belongs to him at that time.
A donor of land stays in heaven for sixty millennia, while a seizer of granted land and a condoner of such seizure shall reside in hell for just as many.
He who would seize land, whether given by himself or by another, imbibes the sin of the slayer of a hundred thousand cows.
In the presence of Traloka Mahādevuka. See the apparatus to line 19. The executor āṇati is Buḍibuggi.
